description: Elijah (Hebrew: Eliyahu, 'My God is YHWH') is one of the greatest prophets in Scripture, known for his fiery confrontation with Baal worship on Mount Carmel and his dramatic ascension to heaven in a chariot of fire. He represents the prophetic tradition at the Transfiguration, appearing alongside Moses (who represents the Law) to speak with Jesus about his impending death in Jerusalem. Jewish tradition expects Elijah's return before the coming of the Messiah, and he is commemorated at every Passover Seder.

transfiguration.significance: Elijah represents the Prophets (Nevi'im) at the Transfiguration, appearing alongside Moses who represents the Law (Torah). Together they testify that all Scripture bears witness to the Messiah.

biblicalReferences.text: After six days Jesus took with him Peter, James and John the brother of James, and led them up a high mountain by themselves. There he was transfigured before them. His face shone like the sun, and his clothes became as white as the light. Just then there appeared before them Moses and Elijah, talking with Jesus.

After six days Jesus took Peter, James and John with him and led them up a high mountain, where they were all alone. There he was transfigured before them. His clothes became dazzling white, whiter than anyone in the world could bleach them. And there appeared before them Elijah and Moses, who were talking with Jesus.

About eight days after Jesus said this, he took Peter, John and James with him and went up onto a mountain to pray. As he was praying, the appearance of his face changed, and his clothes became as bright as a flash of lightning. Two men, Moses and Elijah, appeared in glorious splendor, talking with Jesus. They spoke about his departure (Greek: exodus), which he was about to bring to fulfillment at Jerusalem.

theologicalMeaning: Moses and Elijah represent 'the Law and the Prophets' - the entirety of Hebrew Scripture
Luke's Gospel reveals they discussed Jesus' 'exodus' - his death, resurrection, and ascension
The divine voice 'Hear him' supersedes both Law and Prophets
Peter's suggestion of three tabernacles connects to Sukkot and the Shekinah dwelling
Elijah's presence confirms Jesus as the Messiah whom the prophets foretold
transfiguration.jamesPerspective: As one of only three witnesses to the Transfiguration, James son of Zebedee saw Elijah and Moses in glory, speaking with Jesus about his coming passion. This vision confirmed that all Scripture - Law and Prophets - testified to Christ.

carmel.description: Contest with prophets of Baal; fire fell from heaven
carmel.significance: YHWH alone is God - dramatic defeat of Baal worship

horeb.description: Heard God in the still small voice after fleeing Jezebel
horeb.significance: God's presence in quiet revelation, not just in fire and thunder

transfiguration.description: Appeared in glory with Moses and Jesus
transfiguration.significance: The Prophets bear witness to the Messiah

malachiProphecy.text: Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the great and awesome day of the LORD comes. And he will turn the hearts of fathers to their children and the hearts of children to their fathers, lest I come and strike the land with a decree of utter destruction.
malachiProphecy.significance: Last prophecy of the Old Testament, promising Elijah's return

johnTheBaptist.description: Jesus identified John the Baptist as the fulfillment of Malachi's prophecy
references: Matthew 11:14 - 'If you are willing to accept it, he is Elijah who is to come'
Matthew 17:10-13 - After the Transfiguration: 'Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him'
Luke 1:17 - Angel Gabriel: John will go before him 'in the spirit and power of Elijah'

passoverSeder.description: A cup of wine is set aside for Elijah at every Passover Seder
passoverSeder.significance: Expectation that Elijah will announce the Messiah's coming
passoverSeder.ritual: The door is opened for Elijah during the Seder, symbolizing hope for redemption

circumcision.description: A chair is set aside for Elijah (Kisei shel Eliyahu) at every circumcision ceremony
circumcision.significance: Elijah is called 'the angel of the covenant' and witness to Israel's faithfulness

christologicalSignificance.forerunner: Elijah was the archetype of the forerunner who prepares the way for God's intervention
christologicalSignificance.prophetic_authority: Jesus' ministry reflected Elijah's: confronting religious corruption, performing miracles of provision and resurrection
christologicalSignificance.ascension: Elijah's bodily ascension to heaven prefigured Christ's ascension
christologicalSignificance.twoWitnesses: Some interpret the 'two witnesses' of Revelation 11 as Moses and Elijah returning
